content.description: Face between Carbo and Protein. Get your micro crimp on. Hasn't scene a first assent as far as I know.  Hasn't been climbed in forever. Any taker's?

This is the classic local test piece.  The route is slightly overhanging with positive holds but a sustained cryptic longish crux. This climb can be real pumpy due to its overhanging nature and is a great workout.  An area must do!

A tricky boulder problem on the barely overhung face right of Cheese and Crackers leads to easier, well-protected climbing through stepped dihedrals before ending at the anchors for Cheese and Crackers. Not sustained, but good fun on gear or top rope.
content.protection: Small wires for the boulder problem and a standard rack to 3 inches for the dihedrals.
content.location: Between Cheese and Crackers and Carbo Boy

content.description: Climb the crack to dihedral system to the climber’s right of Cheese and Crackers
content.protection: Standard rack. Can use anchor at Cheese and Crackers

content.description: Follow the low angle slab with a large broken crack on the right. The crux of this climb is at the start. This climb really is nice and easy like cheese and crackers. Goes trad as well. Equipped by P.P.
content.location: This climb is just in front of the large boulder at the bottom of the crag and the third bolted route over from the last bolted climb on the right side of the crag.

content.description: First route right of talus. This is a great climb with an arsenal of fun moves and interesting holds. This climb really goes well after some "Cheese and Crackers".
content.location: This route is located just to the left of "Cheese and Crackers" and just in front of the large boulder at the base of the crag.

content.description: Bottom right of talus. The prominent buttress with a few bulges/roofs. Starts from boulders and traverses right and up through notch in roof/dihedral. Slab to another roof just below junipers.
Delicate slab.  Trust your feet, cuz your hands ain't great.  Equipped by L.P. and P.P.
Start at the base of Greg's Sonic Boom but head immediately right and up.  Stay mostly straight up line, wandering just a little.  Equipped by L.P. and P.P.
Right most route at AAA. Trail to top is just right of start. Short start leads to a diagonal sloped ledge. Though provoking slab leads to fun top.
Furthest left bolted line.  Great textured slab.  Thank god ledge just below anchors.
Great beginner/little person route.  Left side of slab. Many variation's and lots of room to wander. The bolted variation on upper head wall is closer to 5.7
content.protection: 6 bolts plus anchors with rings. SS Fixe Hardware.

content.description: Well bolted route to the climber’s left of Frozen Fingers. Starts on a slightly overhanging face. Pull onto the slab and climb to the anchors. A couple spots will test your friction climbing skills. 9 bolts plus anchors.
content.protection: 9 bolts plus two ring anchors. SS Fixe Hardware.
content.location: Immediately the left of Frozen Fingers.

content.description: Rarely climbed blocky corner to slab. Worth setting up with the other TR's nearby.

Start up the blocky off width crack. Gain the top of pillar / ledge and clip third bolt from this secure stance. Then move left onto a delicate slab and through a balancy sequence. Finish climbing through large blocks/cracks to the right of bolts. 8 bolts plus anchors.
content.location: To the right of Right Flat Iron.

content.description: Short tecnical face to powerful mantel move. Fun slab to top
Left seam route on mini flat iron formation.  Face to Slab.  Great textures.
Start on easy low angle terrain. Climb through the blocky roof utilizing jugs. From large ledge, move onto technical face and finish at ring anchors.
content.protection: Five bolts plus anchors at upper roof

content.description: Follow a nice juggy start on a slightly overhanging wall to the small roof crux at the top of the route. Two ways to finish. Watch out your rope dosen't end up in the pond when you pull the rope.
content.location: This climb is the farthest right bolted route at AAA.

content.description: Thin steeper start leads to thinner crimps with some technical balance higher up.
Thin positive incut crimps down low lead to jug haul higher up. Good varied climbing. May be challenging onsight without the chalk highway to lead the way.

Dirty, body width, flaring crack immediately left of left most bolted line(Greg's Sonic Boom).  Doesn't see much traffic.  Takes good gear, but did I mention dirty.  Do the crag a favor and get on it to keep it clean.
Great short route. Start on aesthetic orange face below an obvious jug. Follow bolt line through crimps, sidepulls, and some compression. Short, stout, and fun.
content.location: To the left of main crag. Walk down road 100 feet past gooble gooble.

content.description: This is a great sport climbing and TR crag with easy access and a great assortment of climbs from 5.4 to 5.12c. This area is broken into three crags, the AAA Wall which has most of the classic routes (#1-18), Buds Wall which was the original TR area just up the road, and Secret Crag with its stout little climbs about 2 miles away.  There is no camping or fires permitted.  Please make sure to park off the road so any traffic can easily pass. The town of Big Bay is about 15 minutes away, just up CR 550 a little more past the turn to AAA and it has two nice bars with decent food and Crams Gas Station and General Store. All in all the AAA wall is an amazing little sport climbing area with a diverse variety of climbs and great access. Please tread lightly and pack out whatever you packed in.It costs the Upper Peninsula Climbers Coalition about $700 a year to purchase liability insurance to maintain access to AAA per an agreement with a local timber company.  If you've ever climbed here and enjoyed it, please think about donating to the UPCC to help keep this gem of a crag open for years to come.See the photo collection for a brief Early History of The AAA Wall.
